arch:property.oc:show_val: Phase IV: Nabataean Grand Design: 1st c. BCE to CE 1st c. The tetrastyle in antis temple is built, including the Porch extension, stylobate, Porch columns, East, West and South Corridor walls, East and West Walkway Walls and the East and West Porch Antae. Additionally, the limestone flooring from Phase II is extended at this time to cover the surfaces of the new corridors and walkways.
Temple expansion into a tetrastyle in antis structure. Construction of the West Corridor Wall.

This locus consists of fragments of plaster that may have originally been on the walls and columns. Two in situ areas of the plaster over Wall Locus 2 were revealed. One was a Pompeiian red, flat, plain area and the second a polychrome area of red, yellow and blue-green. Additionally, these areas had been plastered over and a new design painted over them. A small amount of painted plaster was found near the Erika column with a red and brown banded design. A large quantity of plaster with a blue and black floral motif was found in the center area of the trench. The designs were registered and photographed. There were also many molded pieces of corners, cornices, egg and dart and dentil motifs. A few of these were also registered and saved. The plain flat pieces were colored red, yellow, white, green, blue and black. There is evidence of a plain tessellation being used with the plastering which was common in the Nabataean, as well as the Late Roman and Byzantine periods. An interesting use of the plaster was to "fake" and arch pilaster across from the one in the Wall Locus 5 and the Paul column (Locus 4), discussed previously. Within the collection of fragments, the foundation plaster showed the use of vegetation and plastering nails to bond the plaster to the walls, as well as to the outer layers. Some of the plastering nails were sent to the catalog as representative samples, while the foundation plaster samples were given architectural fragment numbers. The saved plaster was sent to the storage area in SP 38.
